_meta.note: Mom Test-based interview script. Designed to extract real customer behavior and pain points without biasing responses. Use the Interview Playbook for methodology and Interview Questions for the full question bank.

data.methodology: The Mom Test by Rob Fitzpatrick
data.core_principle: Talk about their life, not your idea. Ask about specifics in the past instead of generics about the future. Talk less and listen more.

setup.opening_line: Hey [Name], thanks so much for taking the time to chat. I'm doing research on how people manage their hydration and energy throughout the day. I'm not selling anything - I'm genuinely trying to learn. There are no right or wrong answers, and honestly, the more critical you are, the more helpful it is for me. Sound good?
setup.notes: Smile. Be warm. Make them feel like the expert (because they are). Do NOT mention IonWave, marine plasma, or any product concept yet.

questions.question: Tell me about your health routine - what does a typical day look like for you?
questions.why: Opens the conversation broadly. Listen for unprompted mentions of energy, hydration, fatigue, or supplements.
follow_ups: What made you start doing that?
How long have you been doing it that way?

questions.question: When was the last time you felt really low energy or not great during the day? Walk me through what happened.
questions.why: Gets a specific past event, not a hypothetical. Look for emotional language.
follow_ups: What did you do about it?
How often does that happen?

questions.question: What have you tried to solve that? What's worked and what hasn't?
questions.why: Reveals their solution awareness and what's failed them. Pay attention to WHY things didn't work.
follow_ups: Why did you stop using that?
What was the biggest problem with it?

questions.question: How much time or money do you spend dealing with this?
questions.why: If they're already spending time and money, the problem is real. If not, it might not be painful enough.
follow_ups: Is that worth it to you?
What would you pay for a perfect solution?

questions.question: What's the worst part about this whole thing?
questions.why: Cuts to the emotional core. The answer here is often the best marketing hook.
follow_ups: Tell me more about that.
How does that make you feel?

questions.question: Have you ever told anyone else about this problem?
questions.why: If they talk about it with others, it's a real pain point, not just interview performance.
follow_ups: What did they say?
Did they have the same problem?

questions.question: If this problem was completely solved tomorrow, what would be different about your life?
questions.why: Reveals the desired outcome and the emotional payoff they're seeking.
follow_ups: What would that feel like?
What would you do with that extra energy / time / focus?

questions.question: Are you currently using any electrolyte or hydration product? What is it?
questions.why: Understand current solution and level of category awareness.
follow_ups: How did you find out about it?
Why that one specifically?

questions.question: What do you love about it? What do you wish was different?
questions.why: Identifies competitive strengths to match and weaknesses to exploit.
follow_ups: If you could change one thing, what would it be?

questions.question: Have you looked at switching to something else recently?
questions.why: Active searchers are your best early customers.
follow_ups: What are you looking for?
What's holding you back from switching?

questions.question: Where do you go to learn about new health products? Who do you trust?
questions.why: Reveals your marketing channels and authority sources.
follow_ups: Why do you trust them?
Have you ever bought something based on their recommendation?

questions.question: Is there anything I should have asked you that I didn't?
questions.why: Often reveals the most important insight of the entire interview. People know what matters to them.

questions.question: Who else should I be talking to about this? Anyone in your life who deals with similar stuff?
questions.why: Snowball recruiting for more interviews. Warm intros convert better.
follow_ups: Would you be willing to introduce me?

questions.question: Thanks so much - this was incredibly helpful. Can I reach out again if we build something based on this research?
questions.why: Plants the seed for future engagement. Gets permission for follow-up.

do_not_list.title: Anti-Patterns to Avoid (The Mom Test Rules)

anti_patterns.example: Don't you think an ocean-sourced electrolyte would be amazing?
anti_patterns.why_its_bad: Leading question. Everyone will say yes to be polite. This teaches you nothing.
anti_patterns.instead: Ask what they've tried and what's missing. Let them tell you what they want.

anti_patterns.example: Spending more than 20% of the interview talking about your idea.
anti_patterns.why_its_bad: You're here to learn, not sell. Every minute you talk is a minute you're not learning.
anti_patterns.instead: Ask a question, then shut up. Count to 5 in your head before speaking again.

anti_patterns.example: Would you buy a product that does X?
anti_patterns.why_its_bad: Hypothetical yes means nothing. People are terrible at predicting future behavior.
anti_patterns.instead: Ask about past behavior: 'Have you ever bought...' or 'Tell me about the last time you...'

anti_patterns.example: Letting them say 'Yeah, I sometimes feel tired' without digging deeper.
anti_patterns.why_its_bad: Vague answers don't give you actionable insights. You need specific stories.
anti_patterns.instead: Follow up: 'Tell me about the most recent time. What happened exactly?'

anti_patterns.example: Interviewing friends and family who will never buy your product.
anti_patterns.why_its_bad: Friendly feedback from non-customers is misleading and waste of time.
anti_patterns.instead: Talk to people who match your ICP and are actively dealing with the problem.
